Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Statistical Approach to Signal Processing for Long-Haul Fiber-Optic Communication Sytems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Society depends on fiber-optic networks to carry its huge data demands. Recent literature on optical communications has predicted a plateau in the throughput increase of long-haul fiber-optic communication systems, estimating that the demand for throughput will exceed supply within the next ten years or so. The long term solution to this problem is the systematic replacement of all long-haul fiber (millions of miles just in the US) to more effective fibers. This research project explores a less drastic shorter-term solution. It seeks to answer the following question: if limiting assumptions made in deriving this throughput plateau are relaxed, by using more sophisticated channel modeling and signal processing, can the system capacity be increased sufficiently to delay or even obviate the costly fiber upgrade?

In this project a full probabilistic description of the signal and noise co-propagation through optical fibers is developed so that statistical signal processing approaches can be effectively used on this difficult channel. A probabilistic representation of the fiber-optic system including its correlated, nonstationary, and nonGaussian qualities for wavelength division multiplexed systems and emerging elastic optical networks is first derived. The research includes the derivation of the statistics of each mode of a Gaussian mixture model for the joint signal and noise processes as they propagate through a long-haul fiber. The models developed are used to derive accurate closed-form predictions of the system performance. Signal processing algorithms and receiver designs that optimize the above performance metrics are then developed. The program leverages current models developed for deterministic signals. The focus is in generating accurate yet simple models to make them more generally applicable to both legacy and new optical networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Society depends on fiber-optic networks to carry its huge data demands. These systems are fundamentally limited by unavoidable additive noise and nonlinearity, signal degradations that interact with one another and reduce the network capacity and signal quality. The goal of the project is to understand the interactions between signals and noise in fiber optic systems and to develop signal processing techniques to diminish the resulting physical-layer impairments.

Through this project, contributions were made in modeling fiber-optic systems. We considered both single and multimode fibers, and took a three-pronged approach. We derived mathematical models of the simultaneous propagation of the signal and noise through a long length of fiber, as needed for current continental-scale networks. These probabilistic models were compared with a physical model of the fiber based on characteristics of the material and fiber parameters, for both single and multimode configurations. We then derived computer simulations of the signal propagation using accurate discretized models to validate the accuracy of the mathematical and physical approximations.

We then considered algorithms to counteract the effects of the nonlinear noise; both signal processing and network-management based algorithms were developed. Improvements to the performance of fiber-optic systems were mathematically predicted and then verified using large-scale simulations of both point-to-point systems and large-scale networks.

The project contributed to the training of both undergraduate and graduate students. The training included learning research techniques, teamwork, technical writing, and engineering ethics.
